titleStmt.author: V., I.

publicationStmt.publisher: To the Reader: The English Preface in Print, c. 1475-1640 / Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership

analytic.title: THE TRANSLATOVR TO HIS TRVELY INGENVOVS and most ingenious Authour.
analytic.author: V., I.

monogr.title: Babels balm: or The honey-combe of Romes religion : With a neate draining and straining-out of the rammish honey thereof. Sung in tenne most elegant elegies in Latine, by that most worthy Christian satyrist, Master George Good-vvinne. And translated into tenne English satyres, by the Muses most vnworthy Eccho, Iohn Vicars
monogr.author: Goodwin, George

div.head: THE TRANSLATOVR TO HIS TRVELY INGENVOVS and most ingenious Authour.

lg.l: Gall'd-backed Babel, dost thou kicke and winch,
Enrag'd with smart of Goodwinnes tart Balme-Plaster?
O may it sting thee still, and pricke and pinch
Romes corrupt crue, and her most leprous Master!
God (yet) giue grace, that Some may some Good-win,
Enlightned by Gods guide, to see Romes sin.
Goodwinne did This, One speciall end propound
Of his sweet Satyres: And euen so doe I,
Of my meere Oaten-Pipes plaine rusticke sound,
Wherein poore Pan hath curious Orpheus found,
Needs then (I say) must Mine be all the blame,
Not Thine, if Romes Wilde-beasts be not made tame:
Pardon, I pray (if ought be ill-omitted)

closer.signed: Your most truely louing friend, I. V.
